articles.headline: A Revamping of Bing in the Battle for Search Engine Supremacy
articles.snippet: A Microsoft-Facebook alliance plans an overhaul of Bing in an effort to loosen Google’s grip on the search engine market.
articles.abstract: A Microsoft-Facebook alliance plans an overhaul of Bing in an effort to loosen Google’s grip on the search engine market.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELLEVUE, Wash. — When Facebook goes public in the coming weeks, there will be a lot of winners. Among them is one of the stalwarts of the tech industry, Microsoft, which has a small stake in the company.

articles.headline: Obama Campaign Pushes the Issue of Gay Marriage
articles.snippet: Even as it emerged that Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had apologized to President Obama for hastening his backing of gay marriage, Mr. Obama’s campaign sought to capitalize on it.
articles.abstract: Even as it emerged that Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had apologized to President Obama for hastening his backing of gay marriage, Mr. Obama’s campaign sought to capitalize on it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. apologized to President Obama for hastening him into an endorsement of same-sex marriage, several people briefed on the exchange said Thursday, even as the White House sought to capitalize in the campaign on Mr. Obama’s long-awaited expression of support.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Diet Drug Wins Panel’s Approval
articles.snippet: Government advisers recommended that the F.D.A. approve the weight-loss drug lorcaserin.
articles.abstract: Government advisers recommended that the F.D.A. approve the weight-loss drug lorcaserin.
articles.lead_paragraph: Government advisers recommended approval on Thursday of a weight-loss drug developed by Arena Pharmaceuticals, making it likely that a new obesity treatment will reach the market this year.

articles.headline: The Case for Global Accounting
articles.snippet: Some say that the best hope for international standards would be their enforcement by the United States.
articles.abstract: Some say that the best hope for international standards would be their enforcement by the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, politicians and regulators around the world have claimed to want a common set of high-quality accounting standards that applied globally. The extent to which that rhetoric will become reality may soon become apparent.

articles.headline: China’s Growth Slows, and Its Political Model Shows Limits
articles.snippet: Signs of a slowing economy and recent political upheavals in China add urgency to questions of how much control the state should exert, in business and in the lives of citizens.
articles.abstract: Signs of a slowing economy and recent political upheavals in China add urgency to questions of how much control the state should exert, in business and in the lives of citizens.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHONGQING, China — After the economies of Western nations imploded in late 2008, Chinese leaders began boasting of their nation’s supremacy. Talk spread, not only in China but also across the West, of the advantages of the so-called China model — a vaguely defined combination of authoritarian politics and state-driven capitalism — that was to be the guiding light for this century.

articles.headline: Subsidies Aid Rebirth in U.S. Manufacturing
articles.snippet: There is a quiet realization that American factories need subsidies to survive globally — especially to compete with Asian and European companies that routinely receive government assistance.
articles.abstract: There is a quiet realization that American factories need subsidies to survive globally — especially to compete with Asian and European companies that routinely receive government assistance.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME, N.Y. — Walking through his high-ceilinged factory here, explaining the production of sheets of copper, M. Brian O’Shaughnessy comes across as a staunch advocate of manufacturing in America. But he invariably adds: “There is nothing made in the United States that has to be made here — that can’t be shipped in from some other country.”

articles.headline: Bullying Story Spurs Apology From Romney
articles.snippet: Against the backdrop of President Obama’s same-sex marriage endorsement, Mitt Romney faced fallout over allegations that he had once taunted a classmate who later came out as gay.
articles.abstract: Against the backdrop of President Obama’s same-sex marriage endorsement, Mitt Romney faced fallout over allegations that he had once taunted a classmate who later came out as gay.
articles.lead_paragraph: The day after President Obama endorsed gay marriage, Mitt Romney found himself responding to allegations that as a teenager he harassed a prep school classmate who later came out as gay.
articles.byline: By ASHLEY PARKER  and JODI KANTOR

articles.headline: Murdoch Confidante Recalls Chummy Ties With British Leaders
articles.snippet: Rebekah Brooks’s appearance on Friday before an inquiry into press ethics offered a glimpse into the relationship between political power and the press in Britain.
articles.abstract: Rebekah Brooks’s appearance on Friday before an inquiry into press ethics offered a glimpse into the relationship between political power and the press in Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — They kept in touch, she said on Friday, by telephone, text message and e-mail. They met at lunches and dinners. They socialized at cocktail parties, birthday parties, summer outings, Christmas celebrations and, in one heady instance, on a yacht in Greece.

articles.headline: Gay Marriage Bans May Come at a Price
articles.snippet: As North Carolina voters approved a ban on same-sex marriage this week, executives and business professors were silent on the issue; some say the state may regret the outcome.
articles.abstract: As North Carolina voters approved a ban on same-sex marriage this week, executives and business professors were silent on the issue; some say the state may regret the outcome.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last weekend, former President Bill Clinton took to North Carolina phone lines with a recorded message warning of the perils of a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage and civil unions. “What it will change is North Carolina’s ability to keep good businesses, attract new jobs, and attract and keep talented entrepreneurs,” Mr. Clinton asserted. “If it passes, your ability to keep those businesses, get those jobs and get those talented entrepreneurs will be weakened.”
